text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

This is a tough question for
me because I don't necessarily
think my life has one purpose.

There isn't one thing that
I can point to and say, OK,

once I've accomplished
this, I'll

feel satisfied with
what I've done.

Rather, I think my
experiences have

helped me to find different
parts of my purpose.

As an only child of immigrants
who sacrificed a lot

to get me to where I am,
one big part of my purpose

is being as good a daughter
as I can be because, simply,
my parents deserve the best.

As someone who was raised
far away from family,

but had the privilege of finding
amazing friends and mentors,

another important
part of my purpose

is being there in every way
that I can for the people

that I love, regardless of
what's happening in my life
and career.

And last but not least, a
very big part of my purpose

is trying to improve students'
access to higher quality
education.

Growing up, I was
taught that education

is the key to success,
and I had the opportunity

to go to some amazing
schools with great teachers.

However, while volunteering
at Junior Achievement

in high school, I
realized pretty quickly

and saw firsthand
the stark difference

that 20 miles can make in
the quality of education
that students receive.

So while there are a
lot of things out there

that need improvement, education
is unique, in my opinion,

because it has the ability to
empower students at a young age

and change the trajectory
of entire generations.

Helping students reach
their potential is something

that I aspire to do
throughout my life.

So while this list gets
longer as I get older,

I think these are a few of
the important things that
define my life's purpose.
